Hydroformylation of olefins over a novel active rhodium catalyst supported on a melamine–cyanuric acid co-crystal Valery Zakharov Investigation Methodology Yulia Kardasheva Investigation Writing – original draft ⁎ Vladimir Chernyshev Validation Formal analysis Maria Terenina Investigation Writing – review & editing Konstantin Kalmykov Validation Dmitry Ovsyannikov Investigation Sergey Savilov Validation Svetlana Filippova Validation Edward Karakhanov Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Sergey Dunaev Project administration Leonid Aslanov Writing – original draft Supervision Faculty of Chemistry, Lomonosov Moscow State University, Moscow 119991, Russia Faculty of Chemistry Lomonosov Moscow State University Moscow 119991 Russia Faculty of Chemistry, Lomonosov Moscow State University, Moscow 119991, Russia ⁎ Corresponding author. Hydroformylation, or oxo synthesis, is one of the most important industrial petrochemical processes involving homogeneous catalysts. The development of efficient and stable phosphorus-free heterogeneous catalytic systems for this process is of great interest because it can solve the problem of separation and recycling of expensive metals and reduce the amount of phosphorus-containing waste. Macromolecular compounds containing triazine rings can be promising candidates for supports for the stabilization of metal nanoparticles and subsequent use in heterogeneous catalytic reactions. Herein, it was shown that the interaction of cyanuric chloride with melamine produces cyanuric acid–melamine (CAM) co-crystal, which was used as a support for stabilizing rhodium nanoparticles. The obtained catalyst (CAM/Rh) exhibits high activity and stability in the hydroformylation of olefins of various structures. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst is easily separated from the reaction mixture and can be used repeatedly with virtually no loss of activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Heterogeneous catalysis Olefin hydroformylation Rhodium nanoparticles Cyanuric acid–melamine co-crystal synthesis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In recent years, immobilization of homogeneous metal complex catalysts and metal nanoparticles on solid supports has been studied in numerous works. These catalysts combine the advantages of homogeneous and heterogeneous systems, such as ease of separation and reusability. But one of the main remaining problems of such heterogeneous catalysts is deactivation, which occurs due to the leaching of the metal into the liquid phase [1–3]. In this context, it seems interesting to choose a substrate that would, on the one hand, stabilize catalytically active particles and be able to prevent leaching, agglomeration, and particle growth, and, on the other hand, be thermally and chemically stable and stable under catalytic reaction conditions. Triazine-based materials can be very useful supports, which firmly hold nanosized catalysts due to the electron-withdrawing nature of the triazine ring and the abundance of lone electron pairs on nitrogen atoms [4–7]. Several examples of the use of immobilized transition metal nanoparticles on 2D covalent triazine organic frameworks (CTFs) in catalysis are known from the literature: glycerol oxidation on Pd/CTF nanoparticles [8], aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-diformylfuran on Ru/CTF nanoparticles [9], direct oxidation of methane in concentrated sulfuric acid to methanol in the presence of Pt/CTF and K2[PtCl 4]/CTF [10]. There is also an example of the use of a triazine framework in hydroformylation [11]. Highly porous CTFs were used as supports for the immobilization of rhodium metal complexes and tested in the hydroformylation of 1-octene. The catalytic activity was significantly affected by the porosity and polarity of the support. Mesoporous and less polar supports were more active in hydroformylation than materials with a microporous structure and high polarity. The resulting catalysts retained their activity in four to five consecutive reactions and were superior in activity to Rh/C. Hydrogen-bonded organic frameworks (HOFs are also widely used in many areas of research, e.g., selective gas adsorption and separation/purification of substances [12–14]. A HOF based on cobalt(II) porphyrin [15] showed high catalytic activity and selectivity in the oxidation of ethylbenzene with a quantitative yield of acetophenone of 83.1 % in 20 h at 80 °C. The catalyst hardly lost its activity during six cycles. High activity and stability were demonstrated by a Pd/Au catalyst on a HOF support in the reduction of 4-nitrophenol [16]. In recent decades, interest has increased in phosphorus-free nitrogen-containing catalytic systems for hydroformylation, since they are more resistant to hydrolysis and oxidation, less toxic, and more available in terms of ease of synthesis [17–24]. In this regard, macromolecular compounds containing triazine rings, due to the presence of active nitrogen sites, can be promising candidates for new supports for the stabilization of rhodium nanoparticles and subsequent use in heterogeneous catalytic reactions, in particular, in hydroformylation. In this work, by the interaction of cyanuric chloride with melamine, cyanuric acid–melamine (CAM) co-crystal was obtained (Fig. 1 ). This is a supramolecular compound, in which all molecules within each flat layer are interconnected by hydrogen bonds, thus forming a 2D HOF. The synthesized CAM material was used as a support to stabilize rhodium nanoparticles. The resulting catalyst (CAM/Rh) exhibits high activity and stability in the hydroformylation of olefins of various structures. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The following reagents were used in this work. Pyridine (special purity), which was additionally distilled and stored over A4 zeolite; tripropylamine (TPA); cyanuric chloride (98 %); melamine (pure); dimethylformamide (DMF) (pure); dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) (pure); 1-hexene (97 %); 1-octene (97 %); 1-nonene (97 %); 1-dodecene (97 %); cyclohexene (98 %); and rectified spirit were all purchased from Sigma Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, USA). RhCl3·4H2O (99.9 %), sodium borohydride (98 %), styrene (97 %), toluene (pure), and methanol (99 %) were all purchased from Arcos Organics BVBA (Belgium). Solvents and reagents were purified according to standard procedures [25]. 2.2 Instruments Chemical reactions under high pressure and temperature were performed with an Anton Paar Multiwave PRO system (Anton Paar GmbH, Austria) and a NOVA 2 s microwave system (PreeKem Scientific Instruments Co., Ltd., People's Republic of China). Chemical reactions under atmospheric pressure were carried out with a CEM Focused Microwave TM synthesis system, model Discover (USA). Hygroscopic compounds were handled in a SPECS GBVK sealed vacuum glove box (Russia) with a control unit and one gateway; the pressure during pumping was 10–2 mm Hg. Sonication of the synthesized samples was made with a UZDN-A ultrasonic generator (Russia). Precipitates were separated with a Multi Centrifuge CM 6 M (Elmi Ltd., Rīga, Latvia) at 3500 rpm. 2.3 Preparation of CAM and catalyst (CAM/Rh) 2.3.1 Preparation of CAM in dimethylformamide To prepare CAM, 21 mL of DMF, 9 mmol of melamine, 9 mmol of cyanuric chloride, 3.42 mL of tripropylamine were mixed. The mixture was heated in the Anton Parr microwave reactor in autoclave mode at 140 °C and 150 W for 1 h, including 23 min of heating to 140 °C. The precipitate was centrifuged, the solution was decanted, then the precipitate was washed with water three times under sonication for 20 min, and next the precipitate was washed with ethanol. The precipitate was dried at 100 °C in air, and finally 4.350 g of the substance (CAM) was obtained. Elemental composition of CAM: found: 28.32 % C, 3.92 % H, and 49.32% N; calcd.: 28.24 % C, 3.53 % H, and 49.41% N. The synthesis in dimethylformamide led to a crystalline product, which made it possible to identify it by X-ray powder diffraction methods. In the other organic solvents, e.g., in dimethyl sulfoxide, amorphous substances were obtained. 2.3.2 Preparation of catalyst (CAM/Rh) The catalyst was synthesized by impregnating CAM with a solution of rhodium(III) chloride, followed by reduction with a methanol solution of sodium borohydride. In a round-bottom flask equipped with a stirrer, 30 mg of the support was placed, 4 mL of methanol were added, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min at room temperature. Then, 3.8 mg of RhCl3·4H2O dissolved in 3 mL of methanol was added. The reaction mixture was stirred for 12 h at room temperature. Next, a cooled freshly prepared solution of 1 g of sodium borohydride in 10 mL of methanol was added in portions to the suspension while cooling. The suspension was stirred at reflux for 12 h. After that, the precipitate was separated by centrifugation, washed three times with methanol, and dried in a vacuum. The rhodium content was determined (ISP-AES) to be 3.15 wt%. 2.4 Characterization X-ray powder diffraction patterns were recorded with two powder diffractometers, namely, an Empyrean diffractometer (CuKα radiation, Ni β-filter, Bragg–Brentano geometry) and a Huber G670 Guinier camera (CuK α1 radiation, λ = 1.54059 Å, transmission geometry). The Empyrean diffractometer was used for the quick high-throughput preliminary measurements of all synthesized samples in the low-angle range 5°–40° Elemental analysis was conducted with a CE1106 CHN elemental analyzer (Italy). Nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured with a Micromeritics Gemini VII 2390 surface area analyzer (Micromeritics, Norcross, GA, USA). All samples were degassed at 120 °C for 8 h before analysis. IR spectra were recorded with a Nicolet IR200 spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) using KBr pellets with a resolution of 6 cm–1 in the range 400–4000 cm–1. All the spectra were recorded by averaging 100 scans. The quantitative determination of rhodium in the samples was carried out by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP AES) with an IRIS Intrepid II XDL mass spectrometer (Thermo Electron Corp., USA) at a wavelength of 343.49 nm. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with an Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer (Kratos Analytical, UK). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was made with a LEO EVO 50 xvp electron microscope (Carl Zeiss, Germany) at an accelerating voltage of 25 kV. Images were taken in secondary electron mode. A conductive carbon coating 10 nm thick was preliminarily applied by vacuum arc deposition. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken with a JEOL JEM 2100F/Cs electron microscope (JEOL Co., Ltd) equipped with a field emission electron gun (FEG), a spherical aberration image corrector (CEOS GmbH, Germany), a Tridiem energy filter, and an electron energy loss spectroscopy detector (Gatan Inc., USA). TEM data were obtained at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The data were processed and interpreted using the Digital Micrograph (Gatan), TIA (FEI), and JEMS (Switzerland) software. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were carried out with a NETZSCH STA 449 F1 Jupiter simultaneous thermal analyzer. The heat flows and the mass changes were measured under completely identical conditions in the range from room temperature to 500 °C in a helium atmosphere. The heating rate of the samples was 20 deg/min. 2.5 Procedure for catalytic experiments Hydroformylation was carried out in a 25-mL steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a temperature control device at a syngas pressure of 1.0–5.0 MPa, СО : Н2 = 1 : 1, and temperatures of 80 and 100°С. The autoclave was loaded with 10 mg of catalyst, 2 mmol of olefin, and 2 mL of toluene. The autoclave was sealed, purged three times with syngas, filled to the operating pressure, and heated to the required temperature. The reaction was carried out with continuous stirring for a given time. After cooling to room temperature, the catalyst was separated from the reaction solution by centrifugation and then reused in the reaction. The reaction mixture was analyzed with a Khromos chromatograph (OOO Khromos Inzhiniring, Russia) equipped with a flame-ionization detector and a 50 m × 0.2 mm column (DB-5 phase) at a temperature programmed from 60 to 235 °C and a heating rate of 10 deg/min. The carrier gas was helium (30 mL/min). Conversion (%) was determined from changes in the relative peak areas of the substrate and the products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterizations of CAM The elemental composition of the obtained material and the crystal structure according to the X-ray powder diffraction pattern (Fig. 2 ) are identical to those of cyanuric acid–melamine co-crystal described in the literature [26,27]. In the IR spectrum of CAM (Fig. 3 ), the characteristic appearance of the pair of signals in the range 3400–3200 cm–1 confirms the presence of H–NH hydrogen bonds. The IR spectrum coincides with the CAM spectrum published by Sangeetha et al. [28]. We believe that the formation of CAM occurs at the final stage of the synthesis as a result of the hydrolysis of cyanuric chloride by washing with water. 3.2 Thermal properties of the substrate In the temperature range in which catalytic reactions are performed, CAM is quite stable in a non-aggressive atmosphere (Fig. S1), which agrees with the results obtained earlier [28,29]. The causes of mass loss and the kinetics of the process above 400 °C were discussed by Sangeetha et al. [28]. 3.3 Substrate surface chemistry The chemical compositions of the surfaces of the support and catalyst were determined by XPS. Fig. 4 a shows the survey spectrum. Carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen are present on the surface of CAM; and the high-resolution spectra of the lines of these elements were decomposed into components (Fig. 4b–d, respectively). Table 1 presents the results of assignment. The interpretation was mainly based on the published data [30–33]. The presence of characteristic satellites in the spectra of the lines of nitrogen, oxygen, and carbon indicates the presence of double bonds that form these elements. 3.4 CAM morphology The morphology of CAM crystals was studied by SEM (Fig. 5 ). The material consists of intergrowths of crystals. Agglomeration of crystals leads to a decrease in the specific surface area; however, a large number of steps in crystal intergrowths can favor the strong retention of rhodium nanoclusters, which we deposited on the surface of CAM crystals for catalysis. Fig. 6 shows the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm of a CAM sample (black lines). The shape of the isotherm is close to that characteristic of nonporous materials; however, the narrow hysteresis may indicate the presence of slit-like spaces between the layers formed by CAM crystals. The calculated BET surface area was 24 m2/g, the average slit size was 15 nm, and the total volume was 0.1 cm3/g (Fig. 6). A reference synthesis of CAM in water was performed (Suppl., p. 4). Judging by the X-ray powder diffraction pattern (Fig. S2), the crystallinity of CAM improved significantly in comparison with the sample obtained in dimethylformamide, but the specific surface area was expectedly negligible: 2 m2/g. 3.5 Сharacterization of сatalyst 3.5.1 Low-temperature N2 adsorption–desorption analysis The application of rhodium hardly changes the physical characteristics of the surface of the material (Fig. 6). 3.5.2 XPS The XPS spectrum of a fresh catalyst sample in the Rh3d spectral region contains the doublet with binding energies of the Rh3d 5/2 and Rh3d 3/2 components of 307.1 and 311.8 eV, respectively, which is characteristic of zerovalent rhodium (nanoparticles), and the doublet with energies of 308.3 and 313.1 eV, which characterizes rhodium in the +3 oxidation state in the form of oxide Rh2O3 or chloride RhCl3 [34] (Table 2 , Fig. 7 ). In the spectrum of the used catalyst sample, the doublet with binding energies of the Rh3d 5/2 and Rh3d 3/2 components of 307.1 and 311.8 eV is retained, whereas the doublet with higher binding energies is shifted to 309.0 eV (Rh3d 5/2) and 314.2 eV (Rh3d 3/2), which can be explained by the formation of surface rhodium carbonyl complexes in lower oxidation states during hydroformylation [35]. 3.5.3 TEM The micrographs in Fig. 8 a show that the catalyst contains well-dispersed small particles of spherical shape with a relatively narrow size distribution. The average size of the Rh nanoparticles is 2.2 nm. Particles of a high degree of homogeneity are quite uniformly distributed over the surface of the material without noticeable aggregation. The TEM micrographs (Fig. 8b) and element mapping (Fig. S3) of the catalyst sample after five cycles confirm the uniform distribution of rhodium and point to the absence of aggregation of metal particles during application in catalytic experiments. The particle size distribution also remains virtually unchanged. 3.6 Hydroformylation of 1-octene The catalytic activity was tested by the example of a model reaction of 1-octene hydroformylation at a syngas pressure of 1.0–5.0 MPa, CO : H2 = 1 : 1, and temperatures of 80 and 100°С. GLC showed that the main reaction products are aldehydes with linear (l) and branched (b) carbon chains. A side process, double-bond isomerization, gives a certain amount of a mixture of internal octenes (isooctenes: 2-octene, 3-octene, and 4-octene) (Scheme 1 ); the formation of octane, a hydrogenation product, was not observed under these conditions. At a temperature of 80 °С and a syngas pressure of 5.0 MPa in 5 h, the conversion of 1-octene was 16 % with a selectivity for aldehydes of 50 %. The l/b ratio reached 1.7. An increase in the reaction time (up to 24 h) led to almost quantitative conversion of the substrate into the target products with a simultaneous decrease in regioselectivity (l/b = 1) (Table 3 , entry 2). The effect of the syngas pressure on the reaction results was studied at a temperature of 100 °С in the pressure range of 1.0–5.0 MPa. Table 3 shows that, with an increase in pressure from 1.0 to 3.0 MPa, the yield of aldehydes increases (from 22 to 81 % in 5 h), but the l/b ratio noticeably decreases, which indicates a significant acceleration of the hydroformylation of internal double bonds with an increase in pressure. This result agrees with those previously described in the literature [33]. A further increase in the pressure of the gas mixture does not significantly affect the results of the process. Note that, according to Table 3, at the initial stage of the reaction (in 2 h at 100 °С (entry 6) and in 5 h at 80°С at 5.0 MPa (entry 1), the l/b ratio is noticeably higher than that at high conversions. This suggests that, initially, two parallel reactions occur at approximately equal rates: hydroformylation of 1-octene and double-bond isomerization, which result in the accumulation of internal alkenes and the formation of the main amount of an aldehyde with a linear chain, nonanal, and 2-methyloctanal, the products of hydroformylation of 1-octene. The yield of aldehydes further increases already mainly due to the formation of branched aldehydes, products of hydroformylation of internal octenes, which leads to a decrease in the l/b ratio. The fact that this ratio at 80°С is higher than that at 100°С can be explained by the lower rate of the isomerization reaction under milder conditions (80°С). The data obtained on the hydroformylation of 2-octene (Table 3, entries 8–10) correlate well with the change in regioselectivity during the hydroformylation of 1-octene over time. For example, in 2 h, only 9 % of aldehydes are formed from 2-octene; in 5 h, their yield increases to 88 %; and in 8 h, it becomes quantitative. At the same time, the mixture of aldehydes also contains n-nonanal. In 5 h, 17 % of n-nonanal is formed; and upon achieving quantitative conversion, 19 %. The l/b ratio turns out to be equal to 0.2. The data in Table 3 show that the hydroformylation of 2-octene is also accompanied by a side reaction of isomerization of the double bond position. Table 4 presents the results of the hydroformylation of linear alkenes with different chain lengths, as well as styrene and cyclohexene. In all cases, even in the hydroformylation of the internal double bond of cyclohexene and 2-octene, the catalyst showed high activity, and the yield of aldehydes, as well as the l/b ratio, is independent of the length of the carbon chain of alkenes under the given conditions. Stability is an important aspect of the use of catalysts; therefore, the possibility of the repeated use of CAM/Rh was studied (Fig. 9 ). After the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction solution by centrifugation and decantation, and was used in the next reaction cycle. The catalyst showed high catalytic efficiency without noticeable loss of activity after five repeated uses (Fig. 9). The rhodium content in the catalyst after five cycles of use slightly decreased and was 2.17 wt% according to ICP AES data. At the completion of each catalytic experiment, the liquid phase obtained after separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture was tested for catalytic activity for hydroformylation of 1-octene by adding a fresh portion of the substrate. The reactions were performed under the same conditions as with a heterogeneous catalyst. After the first cycle, noticeable activity of the homogeneous solution was observed: the conversion of 1-octene was about 80 % in 5 h; after the second, the activity was markedly lower (33 %); and after the third and subsequent cycles, the conversion of 1-octene did not exceed 5 %. These data are consistent with the trend of a decrease in the activity of the solid catalyst and indicate that rhodium is washed out into solution, possibly, in the form of soluble carbonyl complexes: the most of the metal was lost after the first use (2.43 wt% of Rh remained in the catalyst; the loss is 23 % of the initial content); then the leaching almost stops, and even after five uses, the rhodium content was more than 70 % of the initial value, which indicates the high stability of the obtained catalyst. These results, as well as the above XPS data on the formation of rhodium carbonyl compounds on the surface of the catalyst, suggest that rhodium nanoparticles immobilized in the CAM material can be considered as a kind of depot of active metal, and hydroformylation can occur in the liquid phase with the participation of rhodium hydride carbonyl complexes formed under the pressure of synthesis gas, which partially decompose after the pressure is released and rhodium from the solution binds again to the nitrogen atoms of the solid substrate. A similar phenomenon was described earlier (see, e.g., [19]). Additional evidence of the reaction occurring in solution under the action of hydride carbonyl complexes can be a low l/b ratio of about 1. 4 Conclusions Herein, by the interaction of cyanuric chloride with melamine, cyanuric acid–melamine (CAM) co-crystal was obtained. A combination of elemental analysis, X-ray powder diffraction analysis, and IR spectroscopy determined that the synthesized material is a supramolecular compound, in which all molecules within each flat layer are interconnected by hydrogen bonds, thus forming a 2D HOF. The produced material was used as a support to stabilize rhodium nanoparticles. Particles of a high degree of homogeneity with a diameter of 2.2 nm are uniformly distributed over the surface of the material without noticeable aggregation. The resulting catalyst exhibits high activity and stability in the hydroformylation of olefins of various structures. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst can be easily separated from the reaction mixture and reused. The catalyst that we developed is promising for use in a number of other processes, such as carbonylation, hydrogenation, etc. CRediT authorship contribution statement Valery Zakharov: Investigation, Methodology. coredata.dc:description: Hydroformylation, or oxo synthesis, is one of the most important industrial petrochemical processes involving homogeneous catalysts. The development of efficient and stable phosphorus-free heterogeneous catalytic systems for this process is of great interest because it can solve the problem of separation and recycling of expensive metals and reduce the amount of phosphorus-containing waste. Macromolecular compounds containing triazine rings can be promising candidates for supports for the stabilization of metal nanoparticles and subsequent use in heterogeneous catalytic reactions. Herein, it was shown that the interaction of cyanuric chloride with melamine produces cyanuric acid–melamine (CAM) co-crystal, which was used as a support for stabilizing rhodium nanoparticles. The obtained catalyst (CAM/Rh) exhibits high activity and stability in the hydroformylation of olefins of various structures. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst is easily separated from the reaction mixture and can be used repeatedly with virtually no loss of activity.
coredata.dc:title: Hydroformylation of olefins over a novel active rhodium catalyst supported on a melamine–cyanuric acid co-crystal
